document.docTitle: Dr. Wolfram Mey’s Stonefly (Insecta: Plecoptera) Collection from Luzon, Philippines: Part I. Perlidae

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Dr. Wolfram Mey’s Stonefly (Insecta: Plecoptera) Collection from Luzon, Philippines: Part I. Perlidae

emphasis.docTitle: Dr. Wolfram Mey’s Stonefly ( Insecta : Plecoptera ) Collection from Luzon, Philippines : Part I. Perlidae

paragraph.emphasis: MS Graduate Fellow, Department of Science and Technology-Science Education Institute, Taguig City 1631, Philippines .
Ateneo Biodiversity Research Laboratory, Department of Biology, School of Science and Engineering, Ateneo de Manila University, Quezon City 1108, Philippines .

subSection.paragraph: Ễ arthien.pelingen@obf.ateneo.edu; https://orcid.org/0000-0002-4869-1918

In this study, the Perlidae stonefly collections of Dr. Wolfram Mey from over 20 years ago have been examined.
Neoperla jhoanae
sp. nov.
from Central Luzon Region and
Neoperla nagaensis
sp. nov.
from Bicol Region are described herein. Additional records and information are also provided on
Neoperla jewetti Sivec, 1984
,
Neoperla recta Banks, 1913
,
Neoperla pseudorecta Sivec, 1984
,
Neoperla oculata Banks, 1924
,
Neoperla nigra Sivec, 1984
,
Phanoperla bakeri ( Banks, 1924 )
, and
Phanoperla flaveola ( Klapálek, 1910 )
.

Key words: alpha taxonomy , distribution ,
Neoperla
, oceanic island ,
Phanoperla

Dr. Wolfram Mey, Curator Emeritus, Museum für Naturkunde, Leibniz, Germany is a renowned specialist in the systematics, biodiversity, and biogeography of Trichoptera, aquatic Lepidoptera and Micro-Lepidoptera of Africa and Southeast Asia. His collection also contains stonefly specimens of the families Perlidae and Leuctridae from Luzon Island, Philippines . I present Part I, Perlidae , of a two-part series on his stonefly collection. Part II, Leuctridae , will be published later.

There are 12 recorded perlid stoneflies from Luzon Island, Philippines , of which nine are
Neoperla Needham, 1905
and three are
Phanoperla Banks, 1938
(Table 1) ( Zwick 1982 ; Sivec 1984 ; Sivec & Stark 2011 ; Pelingen & Freitag 2020 ;
Pelingen et al. 2021
). In a biogeographic perspective, Luzon Island is of great importance to understand the stonefly diversity in the Philippines . It bridges Taiwan to Mindoro-Palawan block, and other oceanic islands of the Philippines such as Marinduque , Romblon , Sibuyan, Panay, Masbate , and Samar . Hypothetically, it can act as a gateway for species migration and colonization as well as a center of speciation due to its varied mountain ranges and inland water bodies.

The representative species of Perlidae from the Philippines were assigned to different species groups and subgroups as suggested by Zwick (1982 , 1983 ) and followed by Sivec (1984) and Sivec & Stark (2011) . Zwick (2023) updated the
Neoperla
genus classification however, in the case of the Philippine species these are still yet to be determined. This makes the study of Philippine Perlidae challenging yet interesting. Because of their diversity, and in some cases close morphological similarities, species assignment can be complicated and may require an integrative approach, in which, for example, DNA barcoding aids in clarifying morphospecies identification ( Pelingen & Freitag 2020 ;
Pelingen et al. 2021
; Pelingen 2024 ). However, historical specimens collected prior to the establishment of barcoding (
Hebert et al. 2003
) may not be suitable for DNA studies. Hence morphological characters are the only means of identification. In this study, the collection dates range from 1997 to 2000 so the specimens are a bit fragile (e.g., see figures of
N. nagaensis
sp. nov.
and
N. pseudorecta Sivec, 1984
below). Ideally, fresh specimens of the newly described and newly recorded species would be collected in the future and be subjected to quality DNA extraction.

caption.paragraph: TABLE 1. Previous Perlidae stonefly records from Luzon Island, Philippines.

subSection.paragraph:
The specimens were examined using a LEICA EZ4 stereomicroscope. Several images at varying focal points of male terminalia and habitus were taken using Canon EOS 6D Mark II and then stacked using Helicon Focus version 5.3. Aedeagus of each specimen was removed from the male terminalia and artificially everted through the cold maceration technique ( Zwick 1982 ). These were then viewed and studied under OLYMPUS CX21 compound microscope. Consequently, a Dino-Lite eyepiece camera was attached to the microscope to photograph varying focal points of the aedeagus and then stacked using Combine ZP ( Hadley 2010 ). All images were enhanced using Adobe Lightroom and Adobe Photoshop. Terminologies follow Zwick (1982) and
Murányi et al. (2015)
.

The holotypes were deposited in the National Museum of Natural History, Manila , Philippines (NMP). Other specimens examined were either stored in the Ateneo Biodiversity Research Laboratory, Ateneo de Manila University, Philippines (AdMU) or in the Museum für Naturkunde, Leibniz, Germany (ZMB) as stated below.

bibRefCitation.author: Needham, J. G.
bibRefCitation.refString: Needham, J. G. (1905) New genera and species of Perlidae. Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington, 18, 107 - 110. [https: // www. biodiversitylibrary. org / page / 2265575]

subSection.paragraph:
Holotype :
1 ♁ adult: “ Philippinen , Luzon \ Zambales Mtn., Coto \ 15̊34’16” N 120̊05’21” E \ 9-10.XI.1998 150 m \ leg. Mey & Speidel”; everted aedeagus inside the same vial submerged in ethanol (NMP).

Description. Imago. Small-sized species. Forewing length of male: 10.0 mm. General color is pale yellow to brownish. Ocelli separated by the diameter of one ocellus. Head pale, M-line distinct, dark mottling distinct in the anterior of tentorial callosities. Antennae darker than head, palpi pale as head. Pronotum nearly trapezoidal with curved corners, narrower than head with eyes, ground color slightly darker than head, rugosities without visible pattern. Meso- and metanotum slightly darker than rest of the body. Legs as dark as pronotum. Tibia and femur are the same color. Wings hyaline, nearly transparent, veins brown. Sterna and terga 2–6 simple, entire abdomen paler than head and thorax.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1.
Neoperla jhoanae
sp. nov. A
habitus; B male terminalia; C aedeagus.

subSection.paragraph: Male terminalia. Posterior of tergum 7 appears to be a wide process studded with sensilla basiconica. Tergum 8 process is strongly raised as a little hook covered with spines on its upper concave side. Hemitergal lobes are normal. Hemitergal anterior processes are short, plump, bent.

Aedeagus. Aedeagal tube slightly short and smooth without spines, with single ventral process covered with spinules; aedeagal sac with basolateral protrusions, midventral spinous hump forming a curvature towards the apex, with small smooth basidorsal lobe like a knob without spines, sac almost covered with spinules extending towards the densely spinous apex.

Differential Diagnosis: The male terminalia of
N. jhoanae
sp. nov.
resembles the common male terminalia of the
recta
species complex i.e.,
N. recta ( Sivec 1984: 10 )
and
N. pseudorecta ( Sivec 1984: 12 )
. However, the aedeagi are completely different from one another based on the presence of basolateral protrusions, midventral hump, and knob-like basidorsal lobe of
N. jhoanae
sp. nov .
Distribution: So far, this species can only be found in Zambales , Luzon Island, Philippines .
Etymology: The species is dedicated to Dr. Jhoana M. Garces for her great contribution to studying the Philippine Ephemeroptera.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2.
Neoperla nagaensis
sp. nov. A
habitus; B male terminalia; C aedeagus.

subSection.paragraph:
Holotype :
1 ♁ adult: “ Philippinen , Luzon \ Naga , Mt. Isarog \ 13̊39’49” N 123̊20’22” E \ 22.3.2000 LF \ leg. Mey & Ebert”; everted aedeagus inside the same vial submerged in ethanol (NMP).

Description. Imago. Medium-sized species. Forewing length of male: 11.0 mm. General color is brownish. Ocelli distant from each other equal to the diameter of one. Coloration of head, antennae, and palpi cannot be accurately determined because of the specimen’s condition. The anterior of the pronotum is distinctly convex, while its posterior is concave with apparent curved corners, the whole pronotum narrower than the head with eyes, without visible pattern. Meso- and metanotum are just a little lighter than the rest of the body. Wings hyaline, nearly transparent, veins brown. Sterna and terga 2–6 simple.

Male terminalia. The anterior part of T7 simple, posterior T7 process with an upper arranged setae and lower sensilla basiconica. Median T8 process close to anterior raised like a hook appearing curved anteriorly with sparse sensilla basiconica. Hemitergites normal with hemitergal processes relatively slender, curved and raised perpendicular to the abdomen in lateral view.

Aedeagus. Aedeagal tube bulky and smooth without spines; sac more slender and shorter than the tube; aedeagal sac slightly curved with two large basolateral lobes and two large basidorsal lobes, all covered with spines; single midventral process heavily covered with spines extending to its spinous apical end of the aedeagal sac.

Differential Diagnosis: The outline and general morphology of the male terminalia and aedeagus of
N. nagaensis
sp. nov.
is so unique that it does not closely resemble any of the Philippine
Neoperla species.
The only similarly looking male terminalia is that of the
recta
species complex having T7 and T8 processes. However, these processes are easily distinguishable from
N. nagaensis
sp. nov
based on its gross appearance alone. In addition, the hemitergal processes of
N. nagaensis
sp. nov.
are also more slender than the representatives of the
recta
species complex.
Distribution: So far, this species can only be found in the Bicol Region of the Philippines .
Etymology: The specific epithet refers to its type locality, Naga .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3.
Neoperla jewetti
. A habitus; B male terminalia; C aedeagus.

bibRefCitation.author: Sivec, I.
bibRefCitation.refString: Sivec, I. (1984) Study of genus Neoperla (Plecoptera: Perlidae) from the Philippines. Scopolia, 7, 1 - 44. [https: // www. zobodat. at / pdf / Scopolia _ 7 _ 0001 - 0044. pdf]

subSection.paragraph:
1 ♁ adult: Philippinen , Zambales Mtn., Coto,
5-6.V. 1999
, 110 m LF, leg. Mey & Ebert, everted aedeagus inside the same vial submerged in ethanol (NMP); 1 ♁ adult: Philippinen , Bicol NP, 200m , 28.03.2000 LF, leg. Mey & Ebert, everted aedeagus inside the same vial submerged in ethanol (AdMU).

Diagnosis. The aedeagus closely resembles the description of
N. jewetti
having the “smallest spiny protrusions distal and the largest proximal; rest of the everted sac covered with fine spinulets except for the stronger spines near the tip” ( Sivec 1984: 20 ). However, the illustration ( Sivec 1984: 21 ) is slightly different from the specimen at hand although the difference may just be attributed to the eversion of the lobes.
Remarks: This species has been recorded previously in Southern Luzon (Mt. Makiling, Los Baños) ( Sivec 1984 ). The new record extends its distribution to Central Luzon.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4.
Neoperla recta
. A habitus; B male terminalia; C aedeagus.

bibRefCitation.author: Banks, N.
bibRefCitation.refString: Banks, N. (1913) On a collection of neuropteroid insects from the Philippine Islands. Proceedings of the Entomological Society of Washington, 15, 170 - 180. [https: // www. biodiversitylibrary. org / partpdf / 8294]

subSection.paragraph:
3 ♁ adults: Philippinen , Luzon, Zambales Mts., Pili,
5-7.XI. 1998
, 150 m, leg. Mey & Speidel, everted aedeagus inside the same vial submerged in ethanol (NMP); 3 ♁ adults: Philippinen , Luzon, Mt. Makiling, 400 m , 14- 16.3.2000 LF, leg. W. Mey, K. Ebert, everted aedeagus inside the same vial submerged in ethanol (AdMU); 6 ♁ adults: Philippinen , Luzon, Laguna , Pangil, 11.4.97, leg. Mey, everted aedeagus inside the same vial submerged in ethanol (AdMU); 7 ♁ adults, Philippinen , Mt. Banahaw, Kinabuyahan, 17- 19.03.2000 , leg. Mey & Richter, everted aedeagus inside the same vial submerged in ethanol (ZMB); 4 ♁ adults: Philippinen , Luzon, Bicol NP., 200m , 28.3.2000 LF, leg. Mey & Ebert, everted aedeagus inside the same vial submerged in ethanol (ZMB); 2 ♁ adults: Philippinen , Mt. Malinao, LF Amater, 25- 26.3.2000 , leg. Mey & Ebert, everted aedeagus inside the same vial submerged in ethanol (AdMU); 3 ♁ adults: Philippinen , Luzon, Naga , Mt. Isarog, 22.3.2000 LF, leg. Mey & Ebert, everted aedeagus inside the same vial submerged in ethanol (AdMU); 2 ♁ adults, Philippinen , Luzon, Santa Fe, Bald Mtn, 1150m , 11-13.XI.97, leg Mey, Ebert, Nuss, everted aedeagus inside the same vial submerged in ethanol (AdMU).
Diagnosis: All material examined here exactly matches the illustration of the Imugin specimen ( Sivec 1984: 10 ).

Remarks: Interestingly, many more
N. recta
individuals have been collected as compared to other
Neoperla species.
In this collection of Dr Mey, the
N. recta
distribution ranges from Zambales Mountains (Central Luzon) all the way to Naga (Southern Luzon).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5.
Neoperla pseudorecta
. A habitus; B male terminalia; C aedeagus.

bibRefCitation.author: Sivec, I.
bibRefCitation.refString: Sivec, I. (1984) Study of genus Neoperla (Plecoptera: Perlidae) from the Philippines. Scopolia, 7, 1 - 44. [https: // www. zobodat. at / pdf / Scopolia _ 7 _ 0001 - 0044. pdf]

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Neoperla pseudorecta Sivec 1984: 11–12
(original description);
Sivec and Stark 2011: 269
(new record).

subSection.paragraph: 3 ♁ adults: Philippinen , Quezon NP LF, Atimonan, 20.03.2000 , leg. Mey & Richter, everted aedeagus inside the same vial submerged in ethanol (ZMB); 4 ♁ adults: Philippinen , Quezon NP LF, Atimonan, 20.03.2000 , leg. Mey & Richter, everted aedeagus inside the same vial submerged in ethanol (AdMU).

Diagnosis: Resembles Busuanga Island specimen of
N. pseudorecta ( Sivec 1984: 12 )
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 6.
Neoperla oculata
. A habitus; B male terminalia; C aedeagus.

bibRefCitation.author: Banks, N.
bibRefCitation.refString: Banks, N. (1924) Descriptions of new neuropteroid insects. Bulletin of the Museum Comparative Zoology, 65, 419 - 455. [https: // www. biodiversitylibrary. org / partpdf / 39698]

subSection.paragraph: 2 ♁ adults: Philippinen , Luzon, Quezon , Infanta, 10.4.1997 , everted aedeagus inside the same vial submerged in ethanol (ZMB); 2 ♁ adults: Philippinen , Luzon, Bicol NP., 200 m , 28.3.2000 LF, leg. Mey & Ebert, everted aedeagus inside the same vial submerged in ethanol (AdMU).
Diagnosis: Exactly like the variation from Rizal ( Sivec 1984: 31 ).
Remarks: The assumed variability of this species was not observed in the new material which also affirms the Luzon distribution of this morphological variation ( Sivec 1984 ).

bibRefCitation.author: Sivec, I.
bibRefCitation.refString: Sivec, I. (1984) Study of genus Neoperla (Plecoptera: Perlidae) from the Philippines. Scopolia, 7, 1 - 44. [https: // www. zobodat. at / pdf / Scopolia _ 7 _ 0001 - 0044. pdf]

subSection.paragraph: 1 ♁ adult: Philippinen , Luzon, Bicol NP., 200m ; 28.3.2000 LF, leg. Mey & Ebert, everted aedeagus inside the same vial submerged in ethanol (AdMU).

Diagnosis: The description and illustration resemble that of
N. nigra ( Sivec 1984: 33 )
, however it looks like the details in the illustration were not that clear. In this specimen, the aedeagus seems to have a more intricate morphology, especially the pair of bare dorsolateral large protrusions and the ventral projection of the conical anterior apex. Nevertheless, its exceptional dark coloration is indisputable even when compared to
N. atropennis Banks, 1924
(
Pelingen et al. 2021: 97
) and
N. sabang Sivec & Stark, 2011
(
Pelingen et al. 2021: 98
).

Remarks: Previously recorded in Mt. Isarog, Camarines Sur , the new record was found in Camarines Norte . Having been found only in this geographical area so far, this species is most likely endemic to the Bicol region.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 7.
Neoperla nigra
. A habitus; B male terminalia; C aedeagus.

bibRefCitation.author: Banks, N.
bibRefCitation.refString: Banks, N. (1938) New Malayan neuropteroid insects. Journal of the Federated Malay States Museum, 18, 221 - 223. [https: // archive. org / details / TLD-BANKS _ 1938 _ 85 / page / n 1 / mode / 2 up]

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Neoperla bakeri Banks 1924: 426
(original description);
Phanoperla bakeri Zwick 1982: 95 : 172
( lectotype designation);
Zwick 1986: 155–157
(new records and probable
bakeri
x anomala hybrids).

subSection.paragraph: 2 ♁ adults: Philippinen , Laguna , Luzon, Pangil, 11.4.1997 , leg. Mey, everted aedeagus inside the same vial submerged in ethanol (NMP); 3 ♁ adults: Philippinen , Mt. Banahaw, Kinabuhayan, 17- 19.3.2000 , leg. Mey & Richter, everted aedeagus inside the same vial submerged in ethanol (NMP); 1 ♁ adult: Philippinen , Zambales Mts.,

Pili, 500m , 7.XI.98, leg. Mey & Speidel, everted aedeagus inside the same vial submerged in ethanol (NMP); 2 ♁ adults: Philippinen , Luzon, Mt. Makiling, LF, 30- 31.3.2000 , leg. Mey & Ebert, everted aedeagus inside the same vial submerged in ethanol (NMP).

Diagnosis: The aedeagus of all specimens examined herein look the same as the illustration by Zwick (1982: 97) . No aedeagus that looks like a probable hybrid ( Zwick 1986: 156 ) was observed from these specimens.

Remarks:
P. bakeri
has already been recorded from Luzon, Mindanao, and Borneo ( Zwick 1982 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 8.
Phanoperla bakeri
. A habitus; B male terminalia; C aedeagus.

subSection.paragraph: 2 ♁ adults: Philippinen , Zambales Mtn., Coto, 110 m , 5-6.V.1999 LF, leg. Mey & Ebert, everted aedeagus inside the same vial submerged in ethanol (NMP).

Diagnosis: The aedeagus and male terminalia look exactly like
P. flaveola ( Zwick 1982: 106 )
.

Remarks: This species is widely distributed in the Philippines in Southern Luzon, Busuanga Island, Palawan , Samar , Leyte , Mindanao. This is the first time it has been recorded in Central Luzon extending its distribution northward.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 9.
Phanoperla flaveola
. A habitus; B male terminalia; C aedeagus.

subSection.paragraph: I would like to express my gratitude to Dr Jhoana Garces for guiding me as her MS Graduate Fellow. Thanks are also due to Mr Marc Ryan Sabordo and Ms Christalle Beatriz Seno for their help in the Ateneo Biodiversity Research Laboratory. Significant appreciation and recognition are extended to Mr Venancio Samarita from the National Museum of the Philippines for his support and partnership during the fieldwork expeditions in the 1990’s– 2000. Lastly, I dedicate this manuscript to Dr Wolfram Mey for entrusting his valuable collection to me.

The graduate fellowship of the author is supported by the Career Incentive Program (CIP) of the Department of Science and Technology - Science Education Institute (DOST- SEI), Philippines . Parts of the academic training were kindly enabled through Biodiversity teaching modules funded by the German Academic Exchange Service (DAAD project BIO-PHIL 57393541). Additional management of aquatic macroinvertebrate material at the Ateneo Biodiversity Research Laboratory were partly supported by the URC Big Project “Integrative Philippine Freshwater Invertebrate Taxonomy and Ecology (Project I FITE-PH): Combating challenges in freshwater conservation, resource management, and environmental biomonitoring through aquatic biodiversity inventory and discovery in selected Philippine islands ,” Ateneo de Manila University, Philippines .
